newsitem.title: INDIA: Bomb blast in Srinagar injures nine people.
newsitem.headline: Bomb blast in Srinagar injures nine people.

text.p: At least nine people were injured when a bomb exploded in a busy marketplace in the heart of Srinagar's business district on Thursday, police said.
The explosive device, placed on a bicycle and apparently targeted at security personnel, went off soon after a vehicle carrying security personnel passed by.
"The blast was so powerful that it damaged the window panes of adjacent buildings," the United News of India agency said.
Police officials told Reuters the bomb exploded in the bustling commercial and residential district of Maghermal Bagh in Srinagar, the summer capital of northern Jammu and Kashmir state.
All nine injured were taken to hospital with two said to be in critical condition.
More than 20,000 people have died in separatist violence in predominantly Hindu India's only Moslem-majority state since an Islamic revolt began in 1990.

Earlier on Thursday, Indian paratroopers raided Mirwaiz Manzil, the home of the Kashmir Valley's chief cleric, Umer Farooq. He is also chairman of the All-Party Hurriyat Conference, the Kashmir valley's largest political grouping.
"They ransacked the office," a Hurriyat spokesman said. "It is littered with overturned furniture and other paraphernalia."
Six people were arrested during the raid, police said in a statement. One of them was Umer Farooq's personal bodyguard.
The statement said the men were militants who led the police to a hidden cache of arms nearby, which included pistols, rifles, some grenades and a wireless set.
Police and officials say there are dozens of separatist groups fighting either for independence or merger of Kasmhmir with neighbouring Pakistan.
A new government led by Chief Minister Farooq Abdullah took power in Kashmir in October after the pro-India National Conference party swept the polls.
New Delhi had ruled the state directly for seven years before that.
